properties.name: Athabasca-Redwater
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamAfter 19 often-tumultuous years in office, Mike Cardinal (PC) is saying goodbye. But voters still have familiar names to choose from. Tory candidate and odds-on favourite Jeff Johnson (PC) is trying to take after dad LeRoy Johnson, the retiring Wetaskiwin-Camrose MLA, while Bill Bonko is the Liberal. Yep, the son of Bill Bonko, Liberal MLA in neighbouring Edmonton-Decore.

properties.name: Dunvegan-Central Peace
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamIn a rare nail-biter in the Tory-loving countryside, Hector Goudreau squeezed through by 341 votes over the Alliance\'s Dale Lueken. For round two, Goudreau expects his campaigners will be less complacent, and that his new cred as a cabinet minister can help sway voters. But Lueken has been in non-stop campaign mode, stirring up the anti-PC mood in this vast but sparsely populated riding.

properties.name: Fort Saskatchewan-Vegreville
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamThey went by the busload in 2006 to back hometown boy Ed Stelmach in his successful Conservative leadership bid, and odds are the premier won\'t have to do much door-knocking here to retain his seat.

properties.name: Lacombe-Ponoka
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamA dark green horse stalks this rural PC stronghold: Joe Anglin, the activist whose landowner group blew the whistle on private investigators hired by the Energy and Utilities Board. The ensuing spying scandal made the board a pariah and Anglin a sort of folk hero. He\'s running as Green party underdog against Ray Prins, a one-term Tory backbencher.

properties.name: Leduc-Beaumont-Devon
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamBeing a former Leduc mayor, and plenty affable, helped Conservative George Rogers win in 2004 by double the runner-up\'s votes. Opposition parties were slow to select candidates this time, but they have them now.

properties.name: Sherwood Park
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamIris Evans has served as Sherwood Park\'s Conservative MLA, reeve or councillor since 1983, and as a Stelmach loyalist she won\'t back down, even at age 66. Nurse and labour leader Louise Rogers of the Liberals will try a third time against Evans.

properties.name: Spruce Grove-Sturgeon-St. Albert
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamHis 599-vote win last time was slim for a Tory outside a big city, but that was before Doug Horner became a senior cabinet minister. Liberal Ray Boudreau will try to narrow that gap in his second attempt. The former Mountie has backing in Spruce Grove, and will bank on St. Albert\'s wavering loyalties to help too. This seat went Grit in 1993 and 1997.

properties.name: St. Albert
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamLiberal Jack Flaherty, a former teacher, surprised even himself by painting this town red last election, knocking off the PC incumbent. At age 74, he\'s surprising others by standing for re-election. He\'ll try to keep it Liberal against former city councillor Ken Allred, the Tory candidate.

properties.name: Stony Plain
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamFirst-term MLA Fred Lindsay reaped the benefits of backing Stelmach\'s leadership bid, and is now a cabinet minister. That gives him an added edge over teacher Bill Fraser, a Liberal Lindsay easily defeated in 2004. This riding has been Tory since Stan Woloshyn crossed the floor from the NDP in 1993.

properties.name: Strathcona
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamSoft-spoken veteran PC MLA Rob Lougheed is leaving politics, so backroom worker Dave Quest is carrying Team Ed\'s banner. Former Liberal leadership candidate Jon Friel will run for his party for a second time.

properties.name: West Yellowhead
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamGruff but popular Conservative Ivan Strang is retiring after three terms, and both the Liberals and NDP will campaign hard in this forestry-and-gas riding they have each held before him. The opposition traditionally banks on labour support, but Tory candidate Robin Campbell heads a coal miners union.
